sell out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: if a shop sells out of something, it has no more of that particular thing left to sell
sell out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: We’ve completely sold out of those shirts in your size, sir.
sell out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: if products, tickets for an event etc sell out, they are all sold and there are none left
sell out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Wow! Those cakes sold out fast.
Tonight’s performance is completely sold out.
sell out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to change your beliefs or principles, especially in order to get more money or some other advantage – used to show disapproval
sell out.translation[0].definitions[2].e: ex-hippies who’ve sold out and become respectable businessmen
sell out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to sell your business or your share in a business
sell out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: Wyman says he’ll sell out if business doesn’t pick up.
The T-mail Co. has sold out to San José-based DMX Inc for an undisclosed sum.
sell out.translation[1].definitions[0].d: a performance, sports game etc for which all the tickets have been sold
sell out.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The concert was expected to be a sell-out.
sell out.translation[1].definitions[1].d: a situation in which someone has not done what they promised to do or were expected to do by the people who trusted them
sell out.translation[1].definitions[1].e: a sellout of the poor for political reasons
sell out.translation[1].definitions[2].d: someone who has not done what they promised to do or who is not loyal to their friends or supporters, especially in order to become more popular, richer etc
sell out.translation[1].definitions[2].e: Many black students regarded him as a sellout.
sell out.translation[2].definitions[0].d: if an investor or owner of a company sells out, they sell their investments or the company
sell out.translation[2].definitions[0].e: Relations between the directors are strained, and shareholders have said they would like to sell out.
They announced that they were selling out to a Japanese company.
sell out.translation[2].definitions[1].d: if a shop sells out of a product, it has no more of that particular product left
sell out.translation[2].definitions[1].e: Some retailers had sold out of the new games console within twenty-four hours.
sell out.translation[2].definitions[2].d: if a product, seats at an event, tickets for a journey etc sell out, there is none left
sell out.translation[2].definitions[2].e: First-class cabins are starting to sell out on some transcontinental flights.
sell out.translation[3].definitions[0].d: if a product, share offer, event etc is a sell-out, it is very successful and lots of people buy it or go there, and no more products, shares, tickets etc are available
sell out.translation[3].definitions[0].e: The $200 million five-year bonds were an absolute sell-out.
